### 1️⃣ What the baseline *actually* is  
When you place a protractor on a vertex, the **baseline** is the side of the triangle that you line up with the straight edge (the bottom edge) of the protractor **and** that also contains the **0° mark** on the protractor’s inner scale.  

- **If the 0° mark is on the left side of the inner scale**, the baseline should be the side that runs **left‑to‑right** in your drawing.  
- **If the 0° mark is on the right side**, the baseline should be the side that runs **right‑to‑left**.

Most classroom protractors have the 0° numbers on the **left** and the 180° numbers on the **right** (when you look at the inner scale). So, in most cases you’ll line the straight edge **along the side that goes from left to right** in your picture.

### 📐 What “baseline” really means

1. **Vertex A** – This is the corner of the angle you’re measuring. It’s the point where the two rays (the two sides of the angle) meet.  
2. **Baseline (or “reference side”)** – This is the **one side of the angle that you line up with the straight edge of the protractor**.  
   * In most textbooks the baseline is the **bottom side** of the angle, the one you place flush against the flat edge of the protractor.  
   * The other side of the angle is the **moving side**; you’ll read the degree number where it intersects the protractor’s scale.

3. **The hole (or “center point”)** – This goes right over the vertex A so the protractor can rotate around the exact corner you’re measuring.

So, **the baseline is *not* the side opposite the vertex**. It’s the side that **touches** the protractor’s straight edge. The opposite side (the side you don’t line up) is simply the other ray of the angle, and that’s the one you’ll read the measurement from.

3. Think of the baseline as the “ground” for the protractor: it’s the line that stays still while the other side of the angle swings up to meet the second ray.

> **Quick mental picture:** Imagine a ruler lying along one side of the angle. That ruler is the baseline. The protractor’s 0‑degree mark sits on the vertex, and the ruler runs along the 0‑degree line.

### 2️⃣ How the right‑angle fits in  

A right‑angle measures **90°**. If you line the baseline with one leg of the angle, the other leg will be exactly **nine “tens”** on the protractor away from the baseline.  

- **If the baseline is along side AB**, then the right‑angle’s other side will intersect the protractor at the **90° mark**.  
- Conversely, if you start from side AC as the baseline, the right‑angle will be measured **90° clockwise** (or counter‑clockwise, depending on which direction you read the protractor).
